TEXT.English: [TAB][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Atlatl[COLOR_REVERT] refers to a person who uses and Atlatl weapon.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]An atlatl or spear-thrower is a tool that uses leverage to achieve greater velocity in spear-throwing, and includes a bearing surface which allows the user to temporarily store energy during the throw. It consists of a shaft with a cup, in which the butt of the spear rests. It is held near the end farthest from the cup, and the spear is thrown by the action of the upper arm and wrist. A well-made atlatl can readily achieve ranges of greater than 100 meters. Atlatl designs may include improvements such as thong loops to fit the fingers, the use of flexible shafts, stone balance weights and thinner, highly flexible darts for added power and range. Darts resemble large arrows or thin spears and are typically from 1.2 to 2.7 meters (4 to 9 feet) in length and 9 to 16 millimetre (3/8” to 5/8”) in diameter.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Atlatls[COLOR_REVERT] as early hunters. They will help you bring food to the nearest city.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Atlatls[COLOR_REVERT] como cazadores iniciales. Ellos te ayudarán a llevar comida a la ciudad más cercana.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A [BOLD]Canoe[\BOLD] is a small narrow boat, typically human-powered, though it may also be powered by sails or small electric or gas motors. Canoes usually are pointed at both bow and stern and are normally open on top, but can be covered.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]In its human-powered form, the canoe is ordinarily propelled by the use of paddles, with the number of paddlers (most commonly two) dependent on the size of the canoe. Paddlers face in the direction of travel, either seated on supports in the hull, or kneeling directly upon the hull. Paddling can be contrasted with rowing, where the rowers usually face away from the direction of travel and use mounted oars (though a wide canoe can be fitted with oarlocks and rowed). Paddles may be single-bladed or double-bladed.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]The oldest recovered canoe in the world is the canoe of Pesse (Holland). According to C14 dating analysis it was constructed somewhere between 8200 and 7600 B.C. This canoe is exhibited in the Drents Museum in Assen, Netherlands.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Canoes[COLOR_REVERT] to explore. You can also carry one unit on them.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Canoas[COLOR_REVERT] para explorar. También puedes llevar una unidad en ellas.

TEXT.English: This early naval unit (the Portuguese replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Caravel[COLOR_REVERT]) can transport both military and peaceful units, as well as explore enemy territory without penalty.

[TAB]These four-masted sailing ships were the first European ships able to reliably navigate the open ocean. Although small by modern standards, the Caravela afforded enough space for crew, cargo and small cannons. Its economy, speed, agility, and power made it esteemed as the best sailing vessel of its time.
This ocean going naval unit can transport both military and peaceful units.

[TAB]These four-masted sailing ships were the first European ships able to reliably navigate the open ocean. As the forerunner of the great ships of the age of sail, the carrack was one of the most influential ship designs in history; while ships became more specialized, the basic design remained unchanged throughout this time period, being large enough to be stable in heavy seas, and roomy enough to carry provisions for long voyages.
Early militia are workers and tradesmen, with little in the form of military training who band together to defend the city.
The militia provide basic city defenses.

[TAB]The English-language surname [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]"Fletcher"[COLOR_REVERT] derives from this term, meaning "one who fletches." It is sometimes generally used for an arrow-maker, not only for someone restricted to this step of the process.

TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Flecheros[COLOR_REVERT] como defensores de ciudades iniciales.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A [BOLD]Gatherers[\BOLD] appeared in the Stone Ages to obtain food for their people. Gatherers obtained up to 80% of the food for their Tribes.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Gatherers[COLOR_REVERT] to improve your land on the Paleolithic and Mesolithic eras.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Recolectores[COLOR_REVERT] para mejorar tu tierra en las eras Paleolítica y Mesolítica.

TEXT.English: Use to engage the heavy privateer and bombard city defences.

[TAB]The heavy frigate first built by the Unoted States Navy and could carry up to sixty guns on two decks. These were so welll armed that they were sometimes considered to be equal to Ships of the Line. Constitution and her sister ships President and United States were created in a response to deal with the Barbary Coast pirates and in conjunction with the Naval Act of 1794. The three big frigates, when built, had a distinctive building pattern which minimised "hogging" (in which the centre of the keel rises while both ends drop) and improves hydrodynamic efficiency.
Stronger than a standard Frigate, but weaker than a Ship of the Line, allowing you to harass your enemies without declaring war.
[TAB] The heaviest privateer ship being capable to withstanding the attentions of the Sloops of War that are the bane of the standard privateers and being able to outrun the Ship of the Line.

Minutemen were members of teams of select militia men, who vowed to be ready for battle within two minutes of receiving notice. The increased range and accuracy of the rifle, along with a lifetime of hunting to develop marksmanship, earned minutemen sharpshooters a deadly reputation.
The minuteman provides city defense and they have a first strike advantage.
The mission of the Police is to safeguard the lives and property of the people in which they serve, to reduce the incidence and fear of crime, and to enhance public safety.
Police provide city protection and they decrease city unrest
Sail gunboats are used to bombard city defences.

In the age of sail, a gunboat was usually a small undecked vessel carrying a single smoothbore cannon in the bow, or just two or three such cannons. A gunboat could carry one or two masts or be oar-powered only, but the single-masted version of about 15 m (49 ft) length was most typical.[when?] Some types of gunboat carried two cannons, or else mounted a number of swivel guns on the railings.
All navies of the sailing era kept a number of gunboats on hand. Gunboats saw extensive use in the Baltic Sea during the late 18th century as they were well-suited for the extensive coastal skerries and archipelagoes of Sweden, Finland and Russia.

[TAB]A [BOLD]Quinquereme[\BOLD] is a type of ancient oar-propelled warship that was used by the Greeks of the Hellenistic period and later by the Carthaginians and Romans, from the 4th century BC to the 1st century. It was developed from the earlier trireme.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Quinqueremes were even more difficult to make stable than triremes, and the increase in speed was not so great as to give the larger galleys much of an advantage. Therefore smaller navies had a core of trireme warships, while bigger navies like Egypt, Rome and Carthage were able to afford a large number of quinqueremes and polyremes. Their advantage was the protection against ramming attacks and the larger body of marines. Comparing the effect of multiple man oars to one man oars you have to look at several men as not fully participating. Because of the restricted movement a large number of rowers did not propel the vessel with as much of their musclepower as on a one man oar. At this time the Greek homeland had declined as a naval power. Only Macedonia's uniting rule was able to afford these juggernauts in larger numbers and with its decline the fleet had to use cheaper triremes again to keep at least a large number of ships in the battleline. But this type of ship had changed into a heavier warship with the rowers now all protected under deck, much more firepower and marines.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Siege Quinqueremes[COLOR_REVERT] to bombard enemy costal cities.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Quinqueremes de Ascedio[COLOR_REVERT] para bombardear ciudades costeras enemigas.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Slavers capture slaves following a successful battle. The slaver only needs be in the same stack as the winning unit in order to capture a slave.

[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Slaves[COLOR_REVERT] are enemies captured and used for slave labour, that are killed upon completion of work. Enemy units can only be captured in this manner if you adopt the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Slavery[COLOR_REVERT] civic.

[TAB]Slaves are workers that are deprived from personal freedom and compelled to work. Slaves are held against their will from the time of their capture, purchase, or birth, and are deprived of the right to leave, to refuse to work, or to receive compensation (such as wages) in return for their labor.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les esclaves sont des ouvriers qui sont privés de la liberté personnelle et obligés de travailler. Des esclaves sont tenus contre leur volonté dès leur capture, achètent, ou naissance, et sont privés de la droite de laisser, de refuser de travailler, ou de recevoir la compensation (telle que des salaires) en échange pour leur travail.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Sklaven sind Arbeitskräfte, die von der persönlichen Freiheit beraubt werden und gezwungen zu arbeiten. Sklaven werden gegen ihren Willen seit ihrer Sicherung gehalten, kaufen oder Geburt und werden das Recht, abzulehnen, oder Ausgleich zu lassen (wie Löhne) als Ausgleich für ihre Arbeit zu empfangen zu arbeiten beraubt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Gli schiavi sono operai che sono privati da libertà personale e sono costretti a funzionare. Gli schiavi sono tenuti contro la loro volontà a partire dal loro bloccaggio, comprano, o la nascita e sono privati della destra lasciare, rifiutare di funzionare, o di ricevere la compensazione (quali gli stipendi) in cambio dei loro lavori.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los esclavos son los trabajadores se obligan que se privan de la libertad personal y que trabajen. Los esclavos se sostienen contra su voluntad desde su captura, compran, o nacimiento, y se privan de la derecha de dejar, de rechazar trabajar, o recibir la remuneración (tal como salarios) a cambio de su trabajo.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Slaves[COLOR_REVERT] are enemies captured and used for slave labour, that are killed upon completion of work. Enemy units can only be captured in this manner if you adopt the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Slavery[COLOR_REVERT] civic, and only by units with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Slaver[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.

[TAB][BOLD]Slinger[\BOLD] is a term that refers to a person who uses a Sling.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]A sling is a projectile weapon typically used to throw a blunt projectile such as a stone. It is also known as the shepherd's sling. A sling has a small cradle or pouch in the middle of two lengths of cord. The sling stone is placed in the pouch. Both cords are held in the hand, then the sling is swung and one of the two cords is released. This frees the projectile to fly on a tangent to the circle made by the pouch's rotation. The sling derives its effectiveness by essentially extending the length of a human arm, thus allowing stones to be thrown several times farther than they could be by hand.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]The sling is very inexpensive, and easy to construct . It has historically been used for hunting game and in combat. Today it still interests sportsmen as a survival tool and as an improvised weapon.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Slingers[COLOR_REVERT] to protect your cities on the Paleolithic era.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Honderos[COLOR_REVERT] para proteger tus ciudades en la era Paleolítica.

TEXT.English: A fast wooden ship strong againt Galleons, Privateers and Brigantines and able to enter Ocean Squares.

[TAB] In the 18th and the earlier part of the 19th centuries, a sloop-of-war was a small sailing warship (also known as one of the escort types) with a single gun deck that carried anything up to eighteen cannons. As the rating system covered all vessels with 20 guns and above, this meant that the term sloop-of-war actually encompassed all the unrated combat vessels including the very small gun-brigs and cutters. In technical terms, even the more specialised bomb vessels and fireships were classed as sloops-of-war, and in practice these were actually employed in the sloop role when not carrying out their specialised functions.
A ship sloop was generally the equivalent of the smaller corvette of the French Navy (although the French term also covered ships up up to 24 guns, which were classed as 'post ships' within the Sixth Rate of the British Navy). The name corvette was subsequently also applied to British vessels, but not until the 1830s.
A sloop-of-war was smaller than a sailing frigate and outside the rating system. In general, a sloop-of-war would be under the command of a master and commander rather than a post captain, although in day-to-day use at sea the commanding officer of any naval vessels would be addressed as "captain". Until 1794 the master and commander strictly speaking held the permenent rank of lieutenant, and reverted to that rank when he gave up command of the sloop-of-war; in 1794 the rank of commander was created. - Wikipedia

[TAB][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Stone Axeman[COLOR_REVERT] refers to a person who carries a Stone Axe.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]During the Neolithic period, large axes were made from flint nodules by chipping a rough shape, a so-called "rough-out". Such products were traded across a wide area. The rough-outs were then polished to give the surface a fine finish to create the axe head. Polishing not only increased the final strength of the product but also meant that the head could penetrate wood more easily.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Such axe heads were needed in large numbers for forest clearance and the establishment of settlements and farmsteads, a characteristic of the Neolithic period. There were many sources of supply, including Grimes Graves in Suffolk, Cissbury in Sussex and Spiennes near Mons in Belgium to mention but a few. In Britain, there were numerous small quarries in downland areas where flint was removed for local use, for example.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Many other rocks were used to make stone axes, including the Langdale axe industry as well as numerous other sites such as Penmaenmawr and Tievebulliagh in Co Antrim, Ulster. In Langdale, there many outcrops of the greenstone were exploited, and knapped where the stone was extracted. The sites exhibit piles of waste flakes, as well as rejected rough-outs. Polishing improved the mechanical strength of the tools, so increasing their life and effectiveness. Many other tools were developed using the same techniques. Such products were traded across the country and abroad.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Stone Axemen[COLOR_REVERT] to counter attack early melee units and to attack cities.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hacheros de Piedra[COLOR_REVERT] para contra-atacar unidades de choque y atacar ciudades.

TEXT.English: [TAB][BOLD]Stone Spearman[\BOLD] is a term that refers to a person who carries a Stone Spear. A Stone Spear consists of a large wood stick with a projectile point on its head.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]In archaeology, a projectile point is an object that was hafted and used either as knife or projectile tip or both, commonly called an arrowhead. Occasionally, projectile points made of worked bone or ivory are found at archaeological sites, but generally the term is reserved for a refined chipped-stone biface. Projectile points fall into two general types: dart points and arrow points. Dart points are defined as those bifaces which were used to tip spears.
Build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Stone Spearmen[COLOR_REVERT] to defend against early Mounted/Wheeled units.
TEXT.Spanish: Construye [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Lanceros de Piedra[COLOR_REVERT] para protegerte de las Unidades a Caballo/Rueda anticipadas.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The galley was the first ship designed for war. Introduced by the Greeks, galleys were powered by banks of oars on each side, manned by well-trained oarsmen. These oarsmen were highly paid professionals or patriotic citizens, not slaves and prisoners as depicted in fiction. A huge, bronze "beak" mounted at the bow of the ship was used to ram and sink enemy ships. Because of its long, narrow hull, the galley was very unstable in all but the calmest waters, and as a consequence its crew rarely ventured out of sight of land for long periods of time, lest the ship be caught in a storm and sunk.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La galère fut le premier navire conçu pour la guerre. Crée par les Grecs, elle était propulsée par plusieurs rangs de rameurs bien entraînés, installés de chaque côté du bateau. Contrairement à ce que l'on pense, ces rameurs étaient des professionnels ou des volontaires, et non des esclaves ou des prisonniers. Un énorme "éperon" en bronze était fixé sur la proue pour éperonner et couler les navires ennemis. La longue coque étroite du bateau le rendait instable dès que la mer s'agitait un peu, et les équipages évitaient généralement de s'aventurer trop longtemps loin des côtes, de peur qu'une tempête survienne et coule le navire.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die von den Griechen in der Antike entworfene und gebaute Triere war das erste Kriegsschiff überhaupt. Auf beiden Seiten des Schiffes befanden sich Ruderbänke, an denen erfahrene Ruderer für volle Fahrt sorgten. Entgegen der häufig vertretenen Theorie, dass es sich dabei um Sklaven oder Gefangene handelte, bestand die Rudermannschaft normalerweise aus gut bezahlten, fachkundigen Seeleuten oder patriotischen Bürgern. Am Bug befand sich ein riesiger, meist aus Bronze gefertigter Schnabel, mit dessen Hilfe feindliche Schiffe gerammt und versenkt werden konnten. Da die Triere wegen ihres langen, schmalen Rumpfs bei rauer See sehr instabil wurde, entfernte sie sich selten weit von der Küste, denn jeder Sturm hätte ausgereicht, um sie zum Kentern zu bringen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La galea è stata la prima nave appositamente progettata per la guerra. Introdotta dai Greci, quest'imbarcazione si muoveva grazie alla presenza di file di remi su ciascun lato, utilizzati da rematori ben addestrati. Questi uomini erano professionisti con un ottimo salario o cittadini patriottici, non schiavi e prigionieri come si crede. Un grosso "rostro" di bronzo, montato sulla prua della nave, veniva utilizzato per colpire e affondare le navi nemiche. A causa del suo scafo lungo e stretto, la galea era molto instabile al di fuori delle acque placide: di conseguenza, l'equipaggio non perdeva mai di vista la costa, proprio per evitare pericoli durante la navigazione.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La galera fue el primer barco diseñado para la guerra. Inventadas por los griegos, las galeras contaban con bancos de remos a ambos lados, manejados por marineros avezados. Los remeros eran profesionales muy bien remunerados o patriotas, no los esclavos y prisioneros que aparecen en las películas. Un enorme ?espolón? de bronce instalado en la proa de la nave se utilizaba para embestir y hundir las embarcaciones enemigas. Debido a su casco alargado y de poco calado, la galera solo era estable en las aguas más tranquilas, y como consecuencia de ello, raramente se alejaba de la costa durante largos periodos de tiempo, no fuera a sucumbir en alguna tormenta.

TEXT.English: War Galley is more combat efficient navy vessel than the Galley and make them better against other early oar based ships. They cannot enter ocean spaces.

[TAB]A [BOLD]Tribe[\BOLD], viewed historically or developmentally, consists of a social group existing before the development of, or outside of, states.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Considerable debate takes place over how best to characterize tribes. Some of this debate stems from perceived differences between pre-state tribes and contemporary tribes; some of this debate reflects more general controversy over cultural evolution and colonialism. In the popular imagination, tribes reflect a way of life that predates, and is more " natural", than that in modern states. Tribes also privilege primordial social ties, are clearly bounded, homogeneous, parochial, and stable. Thus, many believed that tribes organize links between families (including clans and lineages), and provide them with a social and ideological basis for solidarity that is in some way more limited than that of an "ethnic group" or of a "nation". Anthropological and ethnohistorical research has challenged all of these notions.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Anthropologist Elman Service presented a system of classification for societies in all human cultures based on the evolution of social inequality and the role of the state. This system of classification contains four categories:[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Hunter-gatherer bands, which are generally egalitarian.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Tribal societies in which there are some limited instances of social rank and prestige.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Stratified tribal societies led by chieftains.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Civilizations, with complex social hierarchies and organized, institutional governments.
